channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: You smell your coffee in stereo: the brain records an odour’s spatial information
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03386-8

Scent information from the two nostrils leads to two types of neural activity.
item.dc:title: You smell your coffee in stereo: the brain records an odour’s spatial information
item.dc:creator: Saima Sidik

item.title: Nature's Take: How will ChatGPT and generative AI transform research?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03467-8

Nature staff take on the big topics that matter in science.
item.dc:title: Nature's Take: How will ChatGPT and generative AI transform research?
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Magdalena Skipper
Richard Van Noorden
Yann Sweeney

item.title: Why we fall for scams, and the new is bad for the planet: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03468-7

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Why we fall for scams, and the new is bad for the planet: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Are these moths blinding children? Nepalese researchers seek answers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03414-7

Researchers are carrying out environmental surveys and genomic sequencing to try to learn more about SHAPU, a severe eye condition that mainly affects children — but funding is still scarce.
item.dc:title: Are these moths blinding children? Nepalese researchers seek answers
item.dc:creator: Saugat Bolakhe

item.title: Art and science: close cousins or polar opposites?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03389-5

Scientists and artists share a curiosity about the world around them, but do the similarities end there?
item.dc:title: Art and science: close cousins or polar opposites?
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: My path to heading a biotech company
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03471-y

Shadi Farhangrazi describes how she accidentally became a chief executive.
item.dc:title: My path to heading a biotech company
item.dc:creator: Raveena Bhambra

item.title: The world’s week on AI safety: powerful computing efforts launched to boost research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03472-x

UK and US governments establish efforts to democratize access to supercomputers that will aid studies on AI systems.
item.dc:title: The world’s week on AI safety: powerful computing efforts launched to boost research
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Don’t overlook race and ethnicity: new guidelines urge change for psychology research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03458-9

Recommendations aimed at authors, reviewers and editors establish standards for addressing issues that have often gotten short shrift.
item.dc:title: Don’t overlook race and ethnicity: new guidelines urge change for psychology research
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: A robot performs heart surgery with a strong but delicate touch
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03353-3

Device can wield tools inside one of the heart’s chambers while bracing itself against a stabilizer fitted into a major cardiac vein.
item.dc:title: A robot performs heart surgery with a strong but delicate touch

item.title: Potent antibodies have surprise source: people with chronic infections
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03352-4

Bacteria-fighting immune molecules are isolated from people who have long-term infections with the micro-organism Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
item.dc:title: Potent antibodies have surprise source: people with chronic infections

item.title: Cancer trial results show power of weaponized antibodies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03421-8

Tumour-targeting antibodies coupled with toxic chemicals are an unprecedented success in treating bladder cancer.
item.dc:title: Cancer trial results show power of weaponized antibodies
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Asteroid sampler’s hypersonic return thrilled scientists: here’s what they learnt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03318-6

The re-entry of the OSIRIS-REx sample canister is the most closely observed of its type in history.
item.dc:title: Asteroid sampler’s hypersonic return thrilled scientists: here’s what they learnt
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: New explanation for infertility: eggs lacking a mysterious ‘lattice’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03415-6

The discovery of a ‘storage locker’ for essential proteins could explain some cases of infertility.
item.dc:title: New explanation for infertility: eggs lacking a mysterious ‘lattice’
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: Out-of-plane cations homogenise perovskite composition for solar cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06784-0

Out-of-plane cations homogenise perovskite composition for solar cells
item.dc:title: Out-of-plane cations homogenise perovskite composition for solar cells

item.title: Woolly-rhino genome emerges from cave hyena’s fossilized poo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03351-5

Analysis shows that the now-extinct beast split into two populations almost half a million years ago.
item.dc:title: Woolly-rhino genome emerges from cave hyena’s fossilized poo

item.title: A new hydrogel can be directly injected into muscle to help it regenerate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03441-4

A soft and conductive material shows promise for muscle rehabilitation, and why starfishes have such strange body plans.
item.dc:title: A new hydrogel can be directly injected into muscle to help it regenerate
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: How would a starfish wear trousers? Science has an answer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03449-w

Gene expression reveals the story behind starfishes’ strange five-armed body plans
item.dc:title: How would a starfish wear trousers? Science has an answer
item.dc:creator: Shamini Bundell

item.title: Carbon-to-nitrogen single-atom transmutation of azaarenes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06613-4

A new type of transformation converting a heteroaromatic carbon atom into a nitrogen atom, turning quinolines into quinazolines to enable manipulation of molecular properties, is reported.
item.dc:title: Carbon-to-nitrogen single-atom transmutation of azaarenes
item.dc:creator: Jisoo Woo
Colin Stein
Alec H. Christian
Mark D. Levin

item.title: Injectable tissue prosthesis for instantaneous closed-loop rehabilitation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06628-x

An injectable hydrogel for use as a scaffold to aid tissue repair is described, the material of which is conductive so that it can be used both for electrophysiological measurement and electrostimulation in closed-loop robot-assisted rehabilitation.
item.dc:title: Injectable tissue prosthesis for instantaneous closed-loop rehabilitation
item.dc:creator: Subin Jin
Heewon Choi
Duhwan Seong
Chang-Lim You
Jong-Sun Kang
Seunghyok Rho
Won Bo Lee
Donghee Son
Mikyung Shin

item.title: Epigenetic regulation during cancer transitions across 11 tumour types
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06682-5

A pan-cancer epigenetic and transcriptomic atlas identifies epigenetic drivers associated with cancer transitions.
item.dc:title: Epigenetic regulation during cancer transitions across 11 tumour types

item.title: Glioma synapses recruit mechanisms of adaptive plasticity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06678-1

In glioma, malignant synapses hijack mechanisms of synaptic plasticity to increase glutamate-dependent currents in tumour cells and the formation of neuron–glioma synapses, thereby promoting tumour proliferation and progression.
item.dc:title: Glioma synapses recruit mechanisms of adaptive plasticity

item.title: iPS-cell-derived microglia promote brain organoid maturation via cholesterol transfer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06713-1

The authors seek to understand the precise roles of microglia in the early human brain by coculturing brain organoids with primitive-like macrophages generated from the same human induced pluripotent stem cells (iMac).
item.dc:title: iPS-cell-derived microglia promote brain organoid maturation via cholesterol transfer

item.title: Mechanisms of neurotransmitter transport and drug inhibition in human VMAT2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06727-9

Structures of a vesicular monoamine transporter in complex with drugs and substrate provide insights into the physiology and pharmacology of neurotransmitter packaging.
item.dc:title: Mechanisms of neurotransmitter transport and drug inhibition in human VMAT2
item.dc:creator: Shabareesh Pidathala
Shuyun Liao
Yaxin Dai
Xiao Li
Changkun Long

item.title: IL-1β<sup>+</sup> macrophages fuel pathogenic inflammation in pancreatic cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06685-2

Single-cell and spatial gene expression analyses of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma uncover a population of interleukin-1β-expressing macrophages that drive inflammatory reprogramming of neighboring tumour cells leading to disease progression and poor prognosis for patients.
item.dc:title: IL-1β<sup>+</sup> macrophages fuel pathogenic inflammation in pancreatic cancer
item.dc:creator: Nicoletta Caronni

item.title: Molecular evidence of anteroposterior patterning in adult echinoderms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06669-2

RNA tomography and in situ hybridization in echinoderms suggest a new ambulacral-anterior model to relate echinoderm pentaradial symmetry to the ancestral bilateral symmetry.
item.dc:title: Molecular evidence of anteroposterior patterning in adult echinoderms
item.dc:creator: L. Formery
P. Peluso

item.title: Vagal sensory neurons mediate the Bezold–Jarisch reflex and induce syncope
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06680-7

The molecular mechanisms underlying the Bezold–Jarisch reflex and syncope (fainting) involve vagal sensory neurons that express neuropeptide Y receptor Y2, the deletion of which in animal models abolishes the Bezold–Jarisch reflex.
item.dc:title: Vagal sensory neurons mediate the Bezold–Jarisch reflex and induce syncope

item.title: Moon-forming impactor as a source of Earth’s basal mantle anomalies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06589-1

Computer simulations show that mantle material from Theia, a proto-planet theorized to have struck the proto-Earth in the Moon-forming giant impact, may be the source of Earth’s basal mantle anomalies.
item.dc:title: Moon-forming impactor as a source of Earth’s basal mantle anomalies
item.dc:creator: Qian Yuan
Mingming Li
Steven J. Desch
Byeongkwan Ko

Paul D. Asimow

item.title: Neural signal propagation atlas of Caenorhabditis elegans
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06683-4

Measurements of signal propagation in more than 23,000 pairs of neurons from nematode worms show that predictions of neural function made on the basis of anatomy are often incorrect, in part owing to the effects of extrasynaptic signalling.
item.dc:title: Neural signal propagation atlas of Caenorhabditis elegans
item.dc:creator: Francesco Randi
Anuj K. Sharma
Sophie Dvali
Andrew M. Leifer

item.title: Structure of the native myosin filament in the relaxed cardiac sarcomere
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06690-5

A cryo-electron tomography study reports the structure of thick myosin filaments of mouse cardiac muscle in the relaxed state in situ and the MyBP-C links that connect them with the surrounding thin actin filaments.
item.dc:title: Structure of the native myosin filament in the relaxed cardiac sarcomere
item.dc:creator: Davide Tamborrini
Zhexin Wang
Thorsten Wagner
Sebastian Tacke

Michael Grange

Stefan Raunser

item.title: Fossil evidence for a pharyngeal origin of the vertebrate pectoral girdle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06702-4

Computed tomography analysis of the braincase of the Early Devonian placoderm fish Kolymaspis sibirica suggests a skeletal gill support was involved in the origin of the shoulder girdle and provides new evidence reconciling historic theories about the evolution of paired fins.
item.dc:title: Fossil evidence for a pharyngeal origin of the vertebrate pectoral girdle
item.dc:creator: Martin D. Brazeau
Marco Castiello
Amin El Fassi El Fehri
Louis Hamilton
Alexander O. Ivanov
Zerina Johanson
Matt Friedman

item.title: Historical narratives about the COVID-19 pandemic are motivationally biased
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06674-5

How people remember various aspects of the COVID-19 pandemic, including their own behaviour, perception of risk and attitudes towards science and governmental policies, is biased by their perceptions and behaviour today.
item.dc:title: Historical narratives about the COVID-19 pandemic are motivationally biased
item.dc:creator: Philipp Sprengholz
Luca Henkel
Robert Böhm
Cornelia Betsch

item.title: Condensin dysfunction is a reproductive isolating barrier in mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06700-6

Species divergence in condensin regulation and centromere organization between the mice Mus musculus domesticus and Mus spretus drives chromosome decondensation and mis-segregation in their F1 hybrid oocytes, reducing female fertility.
item.dc:title: Condensin dysfunction is a reproductive isolating barrier in mice
item.dc:creator: Warif El Yakoubi
Takashi Akera

item.title: Cryo-EM structure of the human cardiac myosin filament
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06691-4

The intricate molecular architecture and interactions of the human cardiac myosin filament offer insights into cardiac physiology, disease and drug therapy.
item.dc:title: Cryo-EM structure of the human cardiac myosin filament
item.dc:creator: Debabrata Dutta
Vu Nguyen
Kenneth S. Campbell
Raúl Padrón
Roger Craig

item.title: Mouse genome rewriting and tailoring of three important disease loci
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06675-4

This study describes a method to insert large stretches of exogenous DNA into mammalian genomes, which is used to insert human ACE2 loci into mouse to produce a model of human SARS-CoV-2 infection.
item.dc:title: Mouse genome rewriting and tailoring of three important disease loci
item.dc:creator: Weimin Zhang

item.title: Researchers revolt against weekend conferences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03430-7

Parents are pushing for employers to respect family time and keep meetings strictly to working hours.
item.dc:title: Researchers revolt against weekend conferences
item.dc:creator: Amy Coombs

item.title: Close entanglement of the third kind
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03339-1

The circle of life.
item.dc:title: Close entanglement of the third kind
item.dc:creator: Chao Liu

item.title: Daily briefing: Watch the mesmerizing flow of warning signals across a plant’s leaves
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03454-z

See how plants detect their neighbours’ warning messages — plus other fascinating science images. Also, meet the flesh-eating Jurassic ancestors of lampreys and explore how psychedelics work.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Watch the mesmerizing flow of warning signals across a plant’s leaves
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Psychedelic treatments are speeding towards approval — but no one knows how they work
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03334-6

Many questions remain about the formerly taboo chemicals that are being used to treat trauma and depression.
item.dc:title: Psychedelic treatments are speeding towards approval — but no one knows how they work
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Personal motivations polarize people’s memories of the COVID-19 pandemic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03082-7

How accurately a person recalls the COVID-19 pandemic is affected by motivational factors, including how they feel about their vaccination status. The recollections of vaccinated and unvaccinated people are skewed in opposite directions, leading to different retrospective narratives about the pandemic. This distorted recall influences how individuals evaluate past political action, and will complicate preparation for future crises.
item.dc:title: Personal motivations polarize people’s memories of the COVID-19 pandemic

item.title: Atom-swap chemistry could aid drug discovery
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03297-8

An unconventional route for modifying pharmaceutically relevant molecules swaps an atom of carbon for one of nitrogen. The resulting derivatives might open up avenues of research in medicinal-chemistry campaigns.
item.dc:title: Atom-swap chemistry could aid drug discovery
item.dc:creator: Filippo Ficarra
Mattia Silvi

item.title: ‘Groundbreaking’: first treatment targeting ‘super-gonorrhoea’ passes trial
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03448-x

Antibiotic could turn the tide on drug-resistant form of the infection — if it’s used wisely.
item.dc:title: ‘Groundbreaking’: first treatment targeting ‘super-gonorrhoea’ passes trial
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Protect the ‘right to science’ for people and the planet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03332-8

Upholding human rights can ensure that environmental policy is driven by facts and evidence, not denialism, greed and profit.
item.dc:title: Protect the ‘right to science’ for people and the planet
item.dc:creator: Volker Türk

item.title: What causes fainting? Scientists finally have an answer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03450-3

Mouse experiments reveal the brain–heart connections that cause us to lose consciousness rapidly — and wake up moments later.
item.dc:title: What causes fainting? Scientists finally have an answer
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: A radical evolutionary makeover gave echinoderms their unusual body plan
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03123-1

Echinoderms such as starfish are unusual for their five-fold body symmetry. Maps of gene-expression patterns show how this body plan was acquired, and that the genes specifying head structures do the heavy lifting.
item.dc:title: A radical evolutionary makeover gave echinoderms their unusual body plan
item.dc:creator: Thurston Lacalli

item.title: Identification of neuronal connections between heart and brain that trigger fainting
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03076-5

The neural pathways involved in syncope, or fainting, are not well understood. Studies in mice have identified a defined subset of vagal sensory neurons that connect the heart and brain. Stimulation of these neurons causes reduced heart rate, blood pressure, breathing and neuronal activity in the brain, resulting in syncope.
item.dc:title: Identification of neuronal connections between heart and brain that trigger fainting

item.title: The fight to end bullying in academia: UK researchers launch nationwide campaign
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03418-3

Representatives from several UK universities have set up a dedicated advocacy group to which targets of bullying can go for support.
item.dc:title: The fight to end bullying in academia: UK researchers launch nationwide campaign
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Genome rewriting generates mouse models of human diseases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03079-2

Many human diseases lack accurate mouse models because it is technically difficult to create extensively genetically humanized mice. A technique that allows large stretches of DNA to be rapidly rewritten in mouse embryonic stem cells can be used to produce improved animal models.
item.dc:title: Genome rewriting generates mouse models of human diseases

item.title: Getting to the heart of thick-filament structure
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03307-9

Thick filaments contain the protein myosin that generates the force of every heartbeat. Two studies report how these myosin molecules pack together in thick filaments with other proteins to form a surprisingly complex structure.
item.dc:title: Getting to the heart of thick-filament structure
item.dc:creator: Peter J. Knight

item.title: Strange blobs in Earth’s mantle are relics of a massive collision
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03385-9

Impact with a body called Theia 4.5 billion years ago left remnants deep inside Earth — and also created the Moon.
item.dc:title: Strange blobs in Earth’s mantle are relics of a massive collision
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: Keeping secrets in a quantum world
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03336-4

Cryptographers are preparing for new quantum computers that will break their ciphers.
item.dc:title: Keeping secrets in a quantum world
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: Hydrogel implant rehabilitates muscles through electrical stimulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03211-2

An electrically conductive hydrogel injected into an injured muscle can help the muscle to regenerate and reconnect with the nervous system. This effective soft prosthesis has enabled rats to walk soon after muscular injury.
item.dc:title: Hydrogel implant rehabilitates muscles through electrical stimulation
item.dc:creator: Milica Radisic

item.title: Dengue is spreading in Europe: how worried should we be?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03407-6

The post-COVID travel boom combined with a warm summer have led to dengue outbreaks in Italy and France.
item.dc:title: Dengue is spreading in Europe: how worried should we be?
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Sudan’s disastrous war — and the science it is imperilling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03341-7

Ongoing conflict has displaced students and destroyed institutions that were once among Africa’s best. Small projects show how a brighter future can be built
item.dc:title: Sudan’s disastrous war — and the science it is imperilling
item.dc:creator: Mohamed H. A. Hassan

item.title: Daily briefing: Deep-diving seals led scientists to an undiscovered underwater canyon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03427-2

Researchers tracked seals diving deeper in the Antarctic Ocean than would be possible according to existing maps. Plus, mouse embryos in space suggest human babies could develop normally there.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Deep-diving seals led scientists to an undiscovered underwater canyon
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Garbage in, garbage out: mitigating risks and maximizing benefits of AI in research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03316-8

Artificial-intelligence tools are transforming data-driven science — better ethical standards and more robust data curation are needed to fuel the boom and prevent a bust.
item.dc:title: Garbage in, garbage out: mitigating risks and maximizing benefits of AI in research
item.dc:creator: Brooks Hanson
Shelley Stall
Joel Cutcher-Gershenfeld
Kristina Vrouwenvelder
Christopher Wirz
Yuhan (Douglas) Rao
Ge Peng

item.title: Open-access reformers launch next bold publishing plan
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03342-6

The group behind Plan S has already accelerated the open-access movement. Now it is proposing a more radical revolution for science publishing.
item.dc:title: Open-access reformers launch next bold publishing plan
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03333-7

Robust regulation of AI technologies will be crucial to protecting against harms. Researchers’ voices must be heard.
item.dc:title: Why the UK-led global AI summit is missing the point

item.title: Blood-sucking fish had flesh-eating ancestors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03343-5

Two ‘superbly preserved’ fossil lampreys from the Jurassic period help piece together the past of the unusual jawless fish.
item.dc:title: Blood-sucking fish had flesh-eating ancestors
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: Audio long read: Why BMI is flawed — and how to redefine obesity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03257-2

Although body mass index is the main diagnostic test for obesity, it leaves out many factors that can affect how healthy someone is.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: Why BMI is flawed — and how to redefine obesity
item.dc:creator: McKenzie Prillaman
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: The Solar System’s biggest moon is spattered with salt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03354-2

Dried brine from a subsurface ocean speckles the surface of Ganymede, which orbits Jupiter.
item.dc:title: The Solar System’s biggest moon is spattered with salt

item.title: ‘Ash was falling like rain’: how I became a volcanologist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03338-2

Richard Robertson monitors seismic activity across the Lesser Antilles islands in the Caribbean.
item.dc:title: ‘Ash was falling like rain’: how I became a volcanologist
item.dc:creator: Nicola Jones

item.title: Did dust from the Chicxulub asteroid impact kill the dinosaurs?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03406-7

Fine particles kicked up by the collision could have blocked out the Sun for years, resulting in global cooling and disastrous consequences for ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Did dust from the Chicxulub asteroid impact kill the dinosaurs?
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.content:encoded:

Developmental biologist who led team that cloned the first mammal using adult cells.
item.dc:title: Ian Wilmut, embryologist who helped to produce Dolly the sheep (1944–2023)
item.dc:creator: Sarah Franklin

item.title: Consciousness: what it is, where it comes from — and whether machines can have it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03335-5

To understand where artificial intelligence might be heading, we must first understand what consciousness, the self and free will mean in ourselves.
item.dc:title: Consciousness: what it is, where it comes from — and whether machines can have it
